title: Imbalanced Nutrition: Less Than Body Requirements Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing nutritional deficits, focusing on identifying causes of inadequate intake, implementing interventions to improve nutritional status, and preventing complications of malnutrition in patients with various conditions affecting nutrition.

assessments.title: Nutritional Status Assessment
points: Measure height, weight, and calculate BMI
Assess for unintentional weight loss (amount and timeframe)
Evaluate body composition and muscle mass
Perform nutritional screening using validated tool (MNA, MUST, SGA)
Assess for clinical signs of malnutrition (temporal wasting, loss of subcutaneous fat, muscle wasting)
Measure mid-arm circumference and triceps skinfold thickness if indicated
assessments.description: Comprehensive nutritional assessment helps identify the severity of nutritional deficit and guides appropriate interventions

assessments.title: Dietary Assessment
points: Conduct 24-hour dietary recall or food diary review
Calculate estimated caloric and protein intake
Assess for food preferences, allergies, and cultural considerations
Evaluate meal patterns and eating habits
Assess for factors affecting intake (appetite, nausea, dysphagia, dental issues)
Evaluate ability to obtain and prepare food
assessments.description: Dietary assessment helps identify specific nutritional deficits and barriers to adequate intake

assessments.title: Laboratory Assessment
points: Review serum albumin, prealbumin, and transferrin levels
Assess complete blood count for anemia
Evaluate electrolyte levels
Review vitamin and mineral levels (iron, B12, folate, vitamin D)
Assess blood glucose levels
Evaluate thyroid function tests if indicated
assessments.description: Laboratory assessment helps identify specific nutrient deficiencies and metabolic abnormalities requiring intervention

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Imbalanced Nutrition: Less Than Body Requirements related to insufficient dietary intake as evidenced by weight loss and inadequate caloric intake
relatedFactors: Social factors (eating alone, lack of support)
definingCharacteristics: Weight loss with adequate food intake
Body weight 20% or more below ideal weight range
Food intake less than recommended daily allowance
Reported or evidence of lack of food

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Impaired Skin Integrity related to malnutrition

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved nutritional status as evidenced by weight gain or stabilization and increased dietary intake
indicators: Weight stabilization or gain of 0.5-1 kg per week

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate knowledge of nutritional requirements and strategies to improve intake
indicators: Identifies foods high in calories and protein
Identifies barriers to adequate intake and solutions

interventions.title: Nutrition Management
actions: Collaborate with dietitian for individualized nutrition plan
Provide small, frequent, nutrient-dense meals
Implement oral nutritional supplements between meals
Monitor and document intake at each meal (percentage consumed)
Weigh patient at same time of day, with same clothing, 2-3 times per week
Administer vitamin and mineral supplements as prescribed
Consider enteral or parenteral nutrition if oral intake remains inadequate
rationales: Dietitian expertise ensures appropriate nutritional prescription
Small, frequent meals are better tolerated and increase total intake
Supplements provide concentrated nutrition without large volume
Intake monitoring helps evaluate adequacy of nutrition plan
Consistent weighing provides accurate trend data
Supplements correct specific deficiencies
Alternative feeding routes may be necessary for severe malnutrition
specialConsiderations: Consider refeeding syndrome risk in severely malnourished patients
Adjust approach based on underlying cause of malnutrition
Consider cultural and personal food preferences

interventions.title: Eating Disorders Management
actions: Create positive, relaxed eating environment
Provide emotional support during meals
Implement behavioral contracts if appropriate
Address psychological factors affecting intake
Collaborate with mental health professionals if eating disorder suspected
Educate about consequences of malnutrition
Involve family/caregivers in nutrition plan
rationales: Positive environment reduces anxiety around eating
Support reduces stress that may decrease appetite
Contracts provide structure and clear expectations
Psychological factors often contribute to decreased intake
Mental health expertise is essential for eating disorder treatment
Understanding consequences may improve motivation
Family involvement improves outcomes and sustainability

evaluations.statement: Does patient demonstrate knowledge of nutritional needs?
expectedOutcomes: Identifies personal barriers to intake and solutions

references.author: Cederholm T, Jensen GL, Correia MITD, et al.
references.title: GLIM criteria for the diagnosis of malnutrition - A consensus report from the global clinical nutrition community

references.author: Volkert D, Beck AM, Cederholm T, et al.
references.title: ESPEN guideline on clinical nutrition and hydration in geriatrics

notes: Consider nutrition support team consultation for patients with complex nutritional needs or who require specialized feeding approaches
timeFrame: Initial stabilization 1-2 weeks, ongoing management 4-12 weeks

title: Imbalanced Nutrition: More Than Body Requirements Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing excess nutritional intake, focusing on identifying causes of overnutrition, implementing interventions to achieve healthy weight, and preventing complications associated with obesity in patients with various endocrine and metabolic conditions.

assessments.title: Anthropometric Assessment
points: Measure height, weight, and calculate BMI
Measure waist circumference and waist-to-hip ratio
Assess body composition using bioelectrical impedance analysis if available
Evaluate weight history including maximum weight, weight fluctuations, and previous weight loss attempts
Calculate ideal body weight and set realistic weight goals
Assess for physical limitations affecting activity
assessments.description: Comprehensive anthropometric assessment helps quantify excess weight, determine fat distribution patterns, and establish realistic goals

assessments.title: Dietary Assessment
points: Conduct 3-day food diary analysis
Calculate estimated caloric and macronutrient intake
Assess eating patterns (meal timing, portion sizes, snacking)
Evaluate for emotional or stress eating
Assess for food preferences, cultural considerations, and environmental factors
Identify knowledge deficits regarding nutrition
assessments.description: Dietary assessment helps identify specific eating patterns and behaviors contributing to excess intake

assessments.title: Metabolic Assessment
points: Review laboratory values (lipid panel, HbA1c, fasting glucose)
Assess for signs of metabolic syndrome
Evaluate thyroid function
Assess for complications of obesity (hypertension, sleep apnea, joint pain)
Review medication regimen for drugs that may contribute to weight gain
Assess for endocrine disorders affecting metabolism
assessments.description: Metabolic assessment helps identify obesity-related complications and underlying conditions affecting weight management

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Imbalanced Nutrition: More Than Body Requirements related to excessive intake in relation to metabolic needs as evidenced by weight 20% over ideal for height and frame
relatedFactors: Excessive intake in relation to metabolic needs
definingCharacteristics: Weight 20% over ideal for height and frame
Reported or observed excessive food intake
Concentrating food intake at end of day

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Sedentary Lifestyle related to insufficient knowledge of health benefits of physical exercise as evidenced by choice of daily routine lacking physical exercise
definingCharacteristics: Choice of daily routine lacking physical exercise
Verbalizes preference for activities low in physical activity

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate progress toward healthy weight as evidenced by gradual weight loss and improved eating patterns
indicators: Weight loss of 0.5-1 kg per week

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate knowledge of healthy nutrition and lifestyle principles for weight management
indicators: Plans balanced meals using recommended guidelines
Demonstrates understanding of energy balance concept
Identifies triggers for overeating and management strategies
goals.timeframe: Prior to discharge or within 2 weeks

interventions.title: Weight Reduction Assistance
actions: Collaborate with dietitian to develop individualized calorie-controlled meal plan
Establish realistic weight loss goals (1-2 pounds per week)
Implement portion control strategies
Teach meal planning using plate method or exchange lists
Encourage food diary keeping to increase awareness
Develop strategies to manage eating triggers
Provide positive reinforcement for progress
rationales: Dietitian expertise ensures nutritionally balanced caloric restriction
Realistic goals promote success and adherence
Portion control directly addresses excess intake
Structured approaches to meal planning improve nutritional quality
Self-monitoring increases awareness and accountability
Managing triggers reduces non-hunger eating
Positive reinforcement increases motivation and adherence
specialConsiderations: Avoid very low calorie diets without medical supervision
Consider cultural food preferences in meal planning
Adjust approach for patients with binge eating disorder

interventions.title: Exercise Promotion
actions: Assess current activity level and preferences
Develop individualized exercise plan starting with achievable goals
Encourage gradual increase in physical activity (aim for 150 minutes/week)
Incorporate both aerobic and resistance exercises
Teach strategies to incorporate activity into daily routine
Address barriers to physical activity
Monitor response to exercise (heart rate, perceived exertion)
rationales: Assessment ensures appropriate and enjoyable activities
Starting with achievable goals builds confidence and success
Gradual progression prevents injury and promotes adherence
Combined exercise types optimize weight loss and health benefits
Lifestyle integration promotes sustainability
Addressing barriers increases likelihood of participation
Monitoring ensures safety and appropriate intensity

evaluations.statement: Is patient making progress toward weight management goals?
expectedOutcomes: Gradual weight loss (0.5-1 kg per week)

evaluations.statement: Does patient demonstrate knowledge of weight management principles?
expectedOutcomes: Plans balanced meals using recommended guidelines
Verbalizes realistic expectations for weight loss

references.author: Jensen MD, Ryan DH, Apovian CM, et al.
references.title: 2013 AHA/ACC/TOS guideline for the management of overweight and obesity in adults: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines and The Obesity Society

references.author: Yumuk V, Tsigos C, Fried M, et al.
references.title: European Guidelines for Obesity Management in Adults

notes: Consider referral to weight management program, behavioral health specialist, or bariatric surgery evaluation for patients with severe obesity or failed previous weight loss attempts
timeFrame: Initial phase 4-8 weeks, long-term management ongoing

title: Risk for Unstable Blood Glucose Level Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for preventing and managing unstable blood glucose levels, focusing on monitoring, medication management, dietary considerations, and patient education to maintain optimal glycemic control and prevent complications in patients with diabetes or other conditions affecting glucose metabolism.

assessments.title: Glucose Monitoring Assessment
points: Monitor blood glucose levels according to protocol (fasting, pre/post-meals, bedtime)
Assess for patterns of hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia
Evaluate glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels
Assess for signs and symptoms of hyperglycemia (polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, blurred vision)
Assess for signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia (diaphoresis, tremors, tachycardia, confusion)
Evaluate patient's ability to perform self-monitoring of blood glucose
assessments.description: Comprehensive glucose monitoring assessment helps identify patterns of glycemic instability and guides appropriate interventions

assessments.title: Medication Assessment
points: Review current diabetes medication regimen (insulin, oral agents)
Assess medication adherence and administration technique
Evaluate for medication interactions affecting glucose levels
Assess knowledge of medication action, timing, and side effects
Evaluate insulin storage practices
Assess for barriers to medication adherence
assessments.description: Medication assessment helps identify factors related to pharmacological management that may contribute to glucose instability

assessments.title: Lifestyle Assessment
points: Evaluate dietary intake and meal patterns
Assess carbohydrate counting skills if applicable
Evaluate physical activity type, duration, and timing
Assess for alcohol consumption
Evaluate stress levels and coping mechanisms
Assess sleep patterns and quality
Evaluate illness management practices during sick days
assessments.description: Lifestyle assessment helps identify behavioral factors affecting glucose control and areas for education and intervention

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Unstable Blood Glucose Level related to inadequate blood glucose monitoring, dietary intake, medication management, and physical activity
definingCharacteristics: History of unstable blood glucose levels

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Deficient Knowledge related to diabetes self-management as evidenced by inaccurate follow-through of instructions and development of preventable complications

goals.statement: Patient will maintain blood glucose levels within target range
indicators: No episodes of diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate knowledge and skills for effective diabetes self-management
indicators: Identifies signs of hypo/hyperglycemia and appropriate actions

interventions.title: Hyperglycemia Management
actions: Monitor blood glucose levels according to protocol
Administer insulin or oral antidiabetic medications as prescribed
Implement consistent carbohydrate meal plan
Ensure appropriate timing of meals and medications
Encourage adequate hydration
Monitor for signs and symptoms of hyperglycemia
Adjust care during illness, stress, or corticosteroid therapy
rationales: Regular monitoring detects patterns and guides treatment
Appropriate medication administration maintains glycemic control
Consistent carbohydrate intake improves glucose predictability
Proper timing coordinates insulin action with food absorption
Hydration helps prevent hyperglycemic crises
Early detection allows prompt intervention
Stress and illness increase insulin requirements
interventions.frequency: Multiple times daily according to protocol
specialConsiderations: Adjust monitoring frequency during acute illness or medication changes
Consider insulin resistance in critically ill patients

interventions.title: Hypoglycemia Management
actions: Teach patient to recognize early signs of hypoglycemia
Implement the 15-15 rule for mild-moderate hypoglycemia (15g carbohydrate, wait 15 minutes, recheck)
Keep rapid-acting glucose sources readily available
Administer glucagon for severe hypoglycemia as prescribed
Document all hypoglycemic episodes and interventions
Evaluate patterns and causes of hypoglycemia
Adjust medication, meal timing, or activity as needed to prevent recurrence
rationales: Early recognition allows prompt treatment
Standardized approach prevents over-treatment
Immediate availability ensures prompt treatment
Glucagon raises blood glucose in severe cases
Documentation helps identify patterns
Pattern identification guides preventive strategies
Adjustments address underlying causes

interventions.title: Diabetes Self-Management Education
actions: Assess current knowledge and self-management skills
Provide education on blood glucose monitoring technique
Teach medication administration and action
Educate about meal planning and carbohydrate counting
Discuss exercise effects on blood glucose
Teach recognition and management of hypo/hyperglycemia
Provide sick day management guidelines
Discuss importance of preventive care and regular follow-up
rationales: Assessment identifies knowledge gaps
Proper technique ensures accurate readings
Understanding improves medication adherence and timing
Dietary knowledge improves glucose predictability
Exercise awareness allows appropriate adjustments
Recognition skills enable prompt intervention
Sick day protocols prevent serious complications
Regular care prevents long-term complications
interventions.frequency: Daily during hospitalization and prior to discharge

evaluations.statement: Are blood glucose levels maintained within target range?
expectedOutcomes: Blood glucose readings within individualized target range
Decreased frequency and severity of hypo/hyperglycemic episodes

evaluations.statement: Does patient demonstrate effective diabetes self-management knowledge and skills?
expectedOutcomes: Verbalizes understanding of sick day management
